sn36.1:1.1: “Feeling” (vedanā) is the affective or hedonic tone of experience. Each sense can trigger a response of pleasure, pain, or neither-pleasure-nor-pain. It is from the root vid (“know”), and is close in meaning to “experience”. For history, see note at SN 12.1:2.8.
sn36.1:2.1: The text is not explicit as to who speaks these verses. Nor, for that matter, does it say who spoke the prose; the context is elided, presumably because the editors thought it was obvious that it is the Buddha speaking. The same is true of the verses. Indeed, Iti 52 is otherwise identical to this discourse, except it indicates that the Buddha spoke both verse and prose. Whether the verses were added later is a separate matter, but clearly the text presents them as the Buddha’s words.
sn36.1:3.4: By treating the feelings according to the four noble truths, the Buddha is implicitly situating all feelings as suffering.
